project.teaser: In order to protect and manage marine species and habitats, there is an immediate need for the creation of robust evidence-based methods and integrated platforms. Therefore, there is a need to undertake marine research projects that are developed and implemented...
project.objective: In order to protect and manage marine species and habitats, there is an immediate need for the creation of robust evidence-based methods and integrated platforms. Therefore, there is a need to undertake marine research projects that are developed and implemented collaboratively, strategically, and at a sufficient scale. Animal tracking is the study of animal movements across various spatiotemporal scales (local, regional, continental, global; minutes to decades). Although animal tracking is not a new field of research, only recently have these electronic technologies necessary to follow marine animal movements across larger and longer scales have only recently become widely available. Strategic Infrastructure for improved animal Tracking in European Seas (STRAITS) will leverage ongoing acoustic tracking projects across the four corners of Europe (i.e., North Channel, Danish Straits, Straits of Gibraltar and the Bosporus/Dardanelles) by expanding efforts to connect initiatives on species-based biodiversity management while developing data management plans and networking channels to deliver data to national and international governing bodies. Coordinating aquatic animal tracking and environmental observation efforts at a scale that will be usable to make progress on international marine management and planning, is a major step towards an operational European Tracking Network (ETN) that contributes to major European biodiversity initiatives, conservation, and policy.
project.title: Strategic Infrastructure for improved animal Tracking in European Seas
project.keywords: analytics, marine, biodiversity, infrastructure, Telemetry, fish movements, connectivity, marine fauna migrations, integrated data management, multi-species

result.title: Dataset inventory
result.description: A document listing project metadata and datasets currently in the data platform. This document should help other researchers seek help, develop collaborations and apply synergies.

result.title: Communcation, dissemination and exploitation plan (CDEP)
result.description: Development of a communication dissemination and exploitation plan (CDEP) by month 6 (updated every year as needed).

result.title: Design and protocol report
result.description: The document will explain the methodology and technology being used, providing a rationale for the design of each array as well as each partner’s role in the project. The document will serve as the academic and scientific basis for the work as well as an initial introduction to the project for external researchers to plan to utilise the infrastructure.

EGE staff deploying Acoustic Listening Station as part of Turkish array, 2023, credit Aytac Ozgul
Blue shark, Portugal, 2023, credit Michal Babiarz

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: A data management plan will be developed early in the project, which will put together the plans needed to accomplish the STRAITS data platform. This plan will be revised as needed throughout the project.

result.title: Annual tagging report
result.description: Each partner involved in the tagging of aquatic species which will pass by the arrays (LA, DTU, EGE, IFAPA) will produce an annual report summarising the tagging efforts (e.g., no. of individuals tagged, location, methodology, mortality). The first of which will be produced after the first full year of tagging (M26) and then annually (M38 and M48).

result.title: Risk and Action registers
result.description: The Board shall ask the Steering Group to establish a Risk and Action Register for their comment and approval. The PM will monitor the registers on an ongoing basis and report at the monthly Steering Group meetings. The registers will be included in the Group’s monthly report which will go to the Project Board for review at its quarterly meetings.

result.title: Deployment, maintenance and data harvesting
result.description: The lead for each array will be responsible for the deployment of receivers and associated equipment and at least one retrieval per annum for the purposes of maintenance (battery change and cleaning of biofouling as necessary) and the downloading of recorded data. Progress will be monitored via establish project management structures and periodic reviews with PO.Report no.1 on the deployment, maintenance and data harvest will be due no later than M24 of the project. Report no.2 (interim) will be due by M36. Report no.3 (final report) due by M48.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
